node.title: A Border Crisis
node.description: The situation at the Belarus-Poland border is unlike recent immigration crises.
node.content: ["A crowd of migrants trying to cross a border has come to seem appallingly familiar in recent years. We have seen masses of desperate people seek refuge in strange lands: Syrians escaping civil war, the Rohingya brutally driven from Myanmar, Afghans fleeing Taliban rule.", "But the standoff at the border between Belarus and Poland, where thousands of migrants are camped in a freezing forest \u2014 and several have died \u2014 differs sharply. A melee erupted yesterday, the worst clash yet, as hundreds of migrants stampeded a checkpoint and Polish troops fired water cannons and tear gas to quell them. Today, I will explain how the standoff\u2019s origins, relative scale and implications combine to set it apart.", "First, this appears to be an orchestrated crisis, created by Aleksandr Lukashenko, Belarus\u2019s autocratic ruler, to cause trouble for the European Union.", "Belarus allows little in the way of independent news media or meaningful political opposition. Lukashenko\u2019s claim last year to have won re-election with 80 percent of the vote was widely seen as a farce, and hundreds of thousands of people protested.", "The authorities suppressed the demonstrations with force. In response, the E.U. imposed sanctions on Belarus, which is not a member of the union, and Lukashenko dearly wants them lifted.", "In recent months he has allowed in thousands of visitors who want to reach the much freer, wealthier countries of Western and Northern Europe. That means first getting into one of the E.U. member countries that border Belarus \u2014 Poland, Lithuania or Latvia.", "The number of people flowing through Belarus grew sharply in August, most of them Afghans. It surged in the past month with people from Iraq and Syria, many of them ethnic Kurds.", "Lukashenko and his government deny deliberately using migrants to unsettle the E.U. \u2014 while repeatedly threatening to do just that. But the evidence is compelling, starting with the country\u2019s liberal granting of visas to people with one-way airline tickets to Minsk, the Belarusian capital.", "Some migrants have reported being taken to the E.U. borders by the Belarusian authorities, who have urged \u2014 or even forced \u2014 them to cross. They say these authorities gave them wire cutters to breach fences, helped tear down barriers and prevented them from returning to the cities.", "An estimated 4,000 migrants are camped at the Polish border, and perhaps 10,000 to 20,000 on the Belarusian side. The numbers may not be enormous compared with the millions who fled Syria or the million forced out of Myanmar, but the politics of migration are so volatile in Europe that even a small group can set off tensions.", "The right-wing governing party in Poland has long called non-European migrants a threat to Polish culture and sovereignty, and its response to the current group has been predictably heated. It describes the conditions as an attack by Belarus, and has deployed thousands of troops to keep migrants out.", "In 2015-16, more than a million people, primarily Syrians, poured into Europe. The resulting backlash buoyed right-wing nationalists across the continent, and ever since, mainstream politicians have been loath to embrace immigration.", "Six years ago, some countries, notably Germany, welcomed migrants, while others, including Poland, refused to accept more than a few, clashing with E.U. leaders. But there was no danger that the issue would devolve into armed conflict.", "Now, no one is offering to take the migrants, even as they suffer through life-threatening conditions. The E.U. is united behind Poland, which is portraying itself as the first line of defense for the bloc, and Warsaw and Minsk are trading ominous threats.", "Many of the Middle Easterners in Belarus are economic migrants who do not appear to qualify as refugees, though that does not make the danger they face \u2014 at least 11 have died in the cold \u2014 any less real.", "International accords define refugees as people with legitimate fears of violence or persecution, and give them a right to asylum. For many people, the repressive governments in Syria and Afghanistan still pose a severe threat, but the wars there have quieted. Iraq is relatively secure.", "Like Latin Americans who try to illegally enter the United States through its Southern border, many people in Belarus and Poland left Iraq and Syria seeking economic opportunity. They would not qualify for asylum.", "The Polish and Lithuanian authorities have reportedly abused migrants, forcing them back into Belarus. Now the migrants are trapped in a potentially lethal international clash.", "\u201cWe became like a chicken in a cage in the hands of Belarusian and Polish police,\u201d Bayar Awat, an Iraqi Kurd stuck at the border with his wife and infant daughter, said in a telephone interview.", "\u201cOne of them won\u2019t let us go back to Minsk and the other won\u2019t let us in,\u201d he continued. \u201cBelarus is playing with us any way they want.\u201d", "In contrast to many migrant crises, it has been all but impossible for outsiders to know what is really happening in this one.", "Poland and Lithuania barred journalists and human rights groups from the borders, which include some of Europe\u2019s wildest regions and few remaining primeval forests. ", "Belarus, in the last few days, has begun limiting reporters\u2019 access.", "The Polish authorities are engaged in a cat-and-mouse game with migrants along the roads and dirt tracks through the woods. Anti-immigrant sentiment in the region is strong; activists who try to help migrants have found their cars smashed up.", "\u201cIt\u2019s a very tense situation, and it\u2019s so frustrating because there\u2019s such a lack of information,\u201d said Monika Pronczuk, a Times reporter who is just outside the three-mile-wide Polish border strip closed to journalists.", "\u201cWe went into the forest with the activists and we got stopped by soldiers three times on a drive that should be 10 minutes,\u201d she said. They encountered no migrants but found evidence of them: a boarding pass for a flight from Damascus, Syria, to Minsk; a drug prescription written in Arabic.", "These charts \u2014 by Sema Sgaier and Jordan Downey \u2014 show how dangerous it is to be pregnant in America.", "Cozy cabins: Take a cross-country skiing trip through Maine\u2019s wilderness.", "Ask Well: Can you eat the stickers on fruit?", "Letter of Recommendation: An obsession with accidental time travel.", "Advice from Wirecutter: What not to do on your work-issued computer.", "Lives Lived: Ed Bullins, a leading playwright in the Black Arts Movement, wrote for the strivers, hustlers and quiet sufferers whose struggles he sought to capture. He died at 86.", "There was a time when Chinese cuisine was considered \u201ctoo unclean for white Americans to consume,\u201d the food writer Mayukh Sen writes in his new book, \u201cTaste Makers.\u201d In 1945, Chao Yang Buwei, a doctor in her native China, attempted to change that perception. She published America\u2019s \u201cfirst systematically thorough cookbook on Chinese cooking,\u201d explaining techniques like stir-frying. But her talents were hindered by off-kilter English translations of her books, and she never became a household name.", "Sen\u2019s book excavates Chao\u2019s lost history, and those of six other women who changed the American food palate, each from a different country. Along with Chao, the book covers Elena Zelayeta, Madeleine Kamman, Marcella Hazan, Julie Sahni, Najmieh Batmanglij and Norma Shirley.", "The racist, xenophobic and classist injustices the book\u2019s subjects experienced \u201cremain agonizingly apparent within the food industry,\u201d Hetty McKinnon writes in a review. \u201cThe roadblocks that prevented the women\u2019s ascension then are still largely in place today.\u201d", "Still, the book shares its subjects\u2019 achievements through thoughtful, individual stories, examining how they paved the way for generations of chefs and food writers to come. \u2014 Sanam Yar, a Morning writer", "Liberian chicken gravy tastes complex, but comes together in just one pan.", "You\u2019ll want food to snack on before the big meal \u2014 it\u2019s appetizer time.", "Hanif Abdurraqib\u2019s essay collection \u201cA Little Devil in America\u201d is a National Book Award finalist.", "The Barbara Kruger retrospective at the Art Institute of Chicago shows an artist whose definitive style produced an industry of imitators, Jon Caramanica writes.", "The hosts discussed Jonathan Karl\u2019s new book.", "The pangram from yesterday\u2019s Spelling Bee was etymology. Here is today\u2019s puzzle \u2014 or you can play online.", "Here\u2019s today\u2019s Mini Crossword, and a clue: Thick clay pot (five letters).", "If you\u2019re in the mood to play more, find all our games here.", "Thanks for spending part of your morning with The Times. See you tomorrow.", "P.S. A hidden haiku from a Times story about the uncertainty of climate change: \u201cThe important thing / to remember is that there / are no guarantees.\u201d", "Here\u2019s today\u2019s print front page.", "\u201cThe Daily\u201d is about school boards. On \u201cThe Argument\u201d: Does the term \u201cAsian American\u201d mean anything?", "Claire Moses, Ian Prasad Philbrick, Tom Wright-Piersanti, Ashley Wu and Sanam Yar contributed to The Morning.
